text: However widespread they may be on an industrial level, lagers are, in contrast, still a rarity in the craft beer world. Jacks Abby proves that bottom fermentation has more possibilities than most would imagine and in this one, they have transplanted the hop profile of an American style IPA to a bottom-fermented Schwarzbier, thereby effectively creating the black counterpart of IPL (Pilsener with American hops), or indeed a bottom-fermented form of black IPA. Forms a thick, lacing, pale beige, creamy and very stable head over a black robe with chestnut brownish edges only in the outer millimeter or so. Lovely aroma showcasing both the hops and the malts, with impressions of toasted onion, grapefruit peel, pine resin, burnt toast, black olive, cold coffee, walnut, beef jerky, cold black tea, a vague hint of bitter chocolate and some naturally feeling iron. Malty taste from the onset, very low in sweetness, only malt fruitiness with beginning with a pleasant umami taste (cured meat) blending with a slightly caramelly but most of all nutty and toasted malt bittersweetness which turns roasted bitter in the end, including a low sourishness of roasted barley, with a very faint metallic edge; then comes the lush, aromatic New World hop character, piney, grapefruity, peppery, long, drying and still elegant, leaving room for the roasted and toasted maltiness to persist. This is a very pretty beer indeed and surely among the best lagers I had so far - I hope more of these bottom-fermented Cascadian (BIPA-like) beers will appear.

Bottle. Nose is already much bigger than I was expecting, coffee, roast malts, hint of cream, hints of latte, touch of dark chocolate. Taste is roast, malty, hint of honey, toast, smoke, slight citrus and pine hoppiness in the finish. Mouthfeel is rich. 

Im very fond of a good German Schwarz, but Ive never really loved one before, this is a properly brilliant example, with subtlety and depth.

Bottle at home in CT. Pours rich brown with a frothy khaki head. Rich roasted malts in the nose, some cocoa, earth. Medium sweet flavor with hearty baking cocoa, dried tobacco, nicely rounded roasted malts, milk chocolate, a bit of scorched earth. Light to medium bodied with lively, massaging carbonation. Finishes with a richly dynamic chocolate character, more well roasted malts, cocoa, earth, leather, subtle dried berries, a little espresso. Excellent stuff.

Nice sexy presentation with solid black stoutiness and rich foamy head. Taste is very roasty and stout-like. Bitterness is entrenched in the beer like a stout would be-- Im not getting a pilsner type of hoppiness here. I dont drink many stouts anymore, so my interpretation might be off; but I just dont see the difference between this offering of Schwarzbier and a high quality craft-brewed stout. Maybe head to head I would notice the difference, as this beer would have less body. But when I see some call Schwarzbier the "black pilsner," Im just not getting it here. This beer is not merely a black pilsner, but rather a light stout. There is still something to be said for successfully lagering a beer of this richness.

Dark brown, big fluffy head. Aroma of roasted malt, taste is medium bitter, roasty and hoppy, but the taste vanishes quickly without leaving after taste. Decent, expected better after reading the ratings.
Würzig hopfiger Beginn mit angenehmer, später schwächelnder Röstigkeit. Vollmundig, sehr süffig. Röstig herber Nachgeschmack, hopfig. 10/12/11/11/10/11
Bottle from VT shared with Paul. Pours a deep brown body with light tan lacing. Mouthfeel is light to medium with notes of soft roast, dirt, sweet earthy malt, light fruit and grain.

Bottle at home from aleseladark brown-black, fluffy pale tan head, herbal piney bitterness with some roasty notes. Little hoppy character left but probably fairly decrepit at one year old. Nice enough if it were a stout but a tad disappointing as a CD lager.

Deep copper (SRM 23), clear coca-cola color, 
Medium body, intense flavor, moderate alcohol heat but high carbonation, lingering aftertaste. 
Moderately bitter and dry to the finish, sharp and mineral. 
Intense roast flavors, coffee, slightly smoky, hint of sweet malt. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown with a generous tan head. Nose is hoppy-- citrus, herbal, grassy. Tastes caramel, mild notes of chocolate. Big malty backbone with balanced with citrusy hops. Complex, not heavy, finishes mildly bitter. Very nice!

Bottle: Thanks, Jeff. Pours black-hole black with only the darkest of rubies shining through the very edges. A foamy, beige head settles & fizzles quickly to a collar. Up front nose brings pungent, piney hops overshadowing a bold, roasty backbone. Criss-cross of herbal hops, ash, roast, leaves, grass, & a mild kiss of black pepper. Smells almost more like a "Black IPL" than a true Schwarzbier. Taste further confirms that notion. Brash, piney hops collide with your tongue first, over top a heavily roasted malt bill. Notes of bitter citrus peel, grapefruit pith, cocoa powder, ashy roast, burnt bread, a touch of roasted caramel, & herbal leaves. Sharp mouth feel, high carbonation. Like I said, this seems more like the lager version of a Black IPA, but either way, good stuff.

Aroma- mostly smoke and burnt grains. 
Appearance - dark porter color with a frothy off-white head.
Taste - pure smoke and a salty burnt grain flavor. Another one trick pony by Jacks Abby. Aftertaste is fairly bitter and long lasting, like burnt toast. 
This was the one beer of the night we didnt finish. I get what they were going for but it was too overdone for my tastes and lacked anything with regards to subtleness.
Bottle at Craigs...grapefruit and coffee bit of smokiness...pretty thin...not enough body...
Light murky brown, dusty head. Neat nutty, cheap choc and bitter caramel bite. Smooth enough carbonation and finishes a little tinny bitter, linger is coppery. Bottle, ScoIrl tasting
Bottle. Black with tan head. Aroma of grapefruit and coffee, resin. Taste of coffee, grapefruit and pine. Decent body with a bitter finish.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours black, nose is very chocolatey, pine, taste is dry, roasted, chocolate, bitter, fruity.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours dark brown with a thin off-white head. Aromas of chocolate, caramel. Taste is light herbal, more chocolate. Finishes dry, nice.

bottle at home ... dark brown ... big big tan head ... soft sweet toffee charcoal nose soft malts ... soft toffee roast ... dark sweet malts ... dark roast ... light bitter ... real nice balance ... .
Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty piney hoppy caramel aroma. Roasted malty piney hoppy bitter caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty piney hoppy caramel finish.

This one poured a pretty thick head. Not sure if it was supposed to or it was because of the way i poured it. Pretty nice aroma of dark malt as well as some indistinct earthy tones. Taste is mostly dark malt and some mild hops. Its pretty good!

Bottle 50 cl (1 pt 0.9 fl oz) thanks to _angst_! Sampled on October 28, 2014. Marked 7% and 70 IBU.Black color, tan head. Sweet, hoppy, citrus, herbal scent. Bitter, cocoa, citrus taste. Bitter, roasted aftertaste. Medium to full mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Zest,s ome pith, loads of hops. Nice, nut sort of heavy on the citrus for me for something so dark to the roasted side.

Bottle from Bierkompass.de.
Dark red to brown, clear body, with a big, frothy, stable, dark beige head, that leaves a massive lacing.
Aroma of chocoate, coffee, nuts, citrus, pine, resin, dark fruits.
Taste is about the same, also some grass and a slight smokiness.
Quite light, slick to oily mouthfeel, with a moderate carbonation and it finishes bitter, roasty, slightly dry, with coffee, chocolate, pine and lemon zest.

Really interesting! Completely feels like a Black IPA, except that is a bit lighter bodied and easier to drink. I think I couldnt tell it if I didnt know this was a Lager beer. Accomplished and enjoyable.

Bottle bought @ bierkompass.de. Pours black with a rather big frothy blackish beige head that leaves some thick sticky lacing on the glass while dissipating. Smell is malty, tiny fruity, floral and earthy with roasted malts, burnt cereal, caramel, moist grass, pine needles, moist soil, dried flowers, grapefruit rinds and orange zest. Taste is tiny sweet, bitter, tiny malty, floral and earthy with roasted malts, burnt caramel, grapefruit juice, moist grass, pine needles, moist soil, bitter chocolate, butterscotch, orange zest and lemon zest. Mouthfeel is soft, round, slightly astringent and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, bitter, tiny malty and slightly fruity with roasted malts, caramel, cocoa powder, grapefruit juice, moist soil, moist grass, pine needles and orange zest. Bit too sweet but a really solid BIPA.

Bottle thx to _angst_ cons 2014-10-28 Göteborg
AR: plums, tropical fruits, tutti frutti
AP: black, stouthy cream beige head
F: roasted malt, belgian yeasty, soft carbonation, wee tutti frutti, dry feeling
Bottle at Franks, pours black with small head. Notes are rye and ashy as fuck with dark malts, roast, and lager to finish it out. Needed a more dank variety of hops for me to enjoy this one.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2015 From Bottle Shop. Beautiful opaque pitch black. Creamy thick tan head with small fine carbonation. Big streaky foamy legs. Smells strongly of coffee, roasted malt - in a warm, not burnt, way - some cereal and almost cinnamon-y malt, hint of acidic and berry/plum. Great aroma. Tastes quite hoppy, bitter roasted malt that dissipates quickly. Thin-to-medium body, slightly watery. Really enjoyable hoppy dark beer - I love beers that are very dark and very hoppy without getting too burnt or raisin-y like this - but would be even better if there were more to the taste.

Bottle from Bottle Shop at home. Solid black-brown pour with creamy sticky foamy tan head. Aroma is very roasted - coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is pleasantly hoppy for this type of beer - good amount of bitterness and pine. Then more typical dark beer flavors. Not too heavy either. Lasting bitterness. Quite good. Would get again.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; dark brown almost black pour with a big fluffy light tan head, mellow pine and roast malt aroma, taste has dark fruits, bitter coffee, resinous pine, sweet chocolate, really nice viscous mouthfeel.

500ml bottle from Bierkompass
MFG 03.11.14 - Pours pitch black with a thick light brown head. Aroma of earthy notes, grassy hops, roasty malts, hints of licorice, smoke and ash. Taste is crisp, malty and earthy with loads of grassy hops, roastiness, lingering bitterness, licorice and hints of smoke. Finish is bitter, crisp and massively hoppy with some roastiness, notes of licorice and tar. Quite nice and tasty beer. Feels almost like a black IPA.

50 cl bottle (7%) @ home, brewed 11.03.2014
A 7% schwartz? Shouldnt this be a dunkler bock?

Aroma has nice roastiness, chocolate and coffee. Also hints of hay. Flavour is somewhat hoppy with ashy tones, cold coffee, some licorice and hints of smoke. The hops feel vegetable-like on some sips. A schwartz on the hoppy side, does not reach the hoppiness level of Black IPA though.

7th September 2014Almost opaque dark brown beer, tidy pale tan head. Palate is crispy and semi dry. Roasty dark malts but delivered in a light and smooth fashion. Touch of dry dark chocolate. Good light piney hops, trace of citrus. Light dry finish. Stands on the cusp of being a CDA I would venture. Very drinkable.

500ml bottle. Jet black colour with huge, thick, frothy to creamy, fairly lasting and lacing, beige head. Black IPA-ish aroma, roasty dark malty, dark chocolately and resinous hoppy notes converge into green onion flavours; overall theres a predominance on the richer malty side, delivering additionally hints of coffee, cocoa, milk chocolate. Taste is bitter hoppy, roasty dark malty, hints of dark chocolate, cold mocha, an earthy, resinous hoppy touch, some citrusy hoppy overtones as well, even a salty touch of liquorice. Very well balanced, at the same time diversified, oscillating between different flavours, delivering new subset combinations with every sip, depending on the focus of your advertency - too complex to determine the flavours all at once.

Bottle. Pours dark mahogny in color with an off-white head. Upfront you get chocolate, dark roasted malts, floral notes and forresty pine in aroma. Roasted malts, coffee and burnt wood in taste with a nice bitterness backing it up. Quite smooth mouthfeel too. Then theres that grapefruit bitterness and toffee sweetness mixed together with coffee and pine in the finish. Really nice and delicious brew.
Awesome. Clear brown, beige head. Great balance of hops, some light smoke, roast. Tasty.
Smell bright roasty hoppy clean nice. Taste same. Light roasty flavor body.Very nice stuff.
16.9 oz bottle pours black with a tan head. Aroma of citrus, pine malts and floral. Taste is malts, citrus and pine.

Bottle from the brewery. Pitch black with a pretty, high, tan head. Aroma of chocolate malts, coffee, and hops, citrus and pine. Full flavor, chocolate dominates but a good deal of roasty coffee as well, more than I prefer, actually, and great hops all around. Bitter hop and roast finish. It is interesting to try to think about the lager characteristics of this. Definitely drinks like a black IPA. Enjoyable.

Bottle. Clear dark brown with a foamy, tan head that lasts and laces. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, pine, coffee, and light grapefruit. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, grapefruit, pine, coffee and light dark fruit notes. Medium bodied, crisp with a dry and bitter finish. Lingering roastiness.

Pours a deep black with small beige head. Aroma is woody cedar, pine hop, smoke, grassy hop, cocoa, coffee, caramel. Flavor is medium bitter, smokey, fresh grassy pine hop. Med mouthfeel, sweet chocolate / cocoa / and pine hop dry bitter finish.

Bottle 500ml.
Pours very dark brown with medium beige head. Good lacing. Some resin. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, fruits, coffee. Taste is of roasted malt, chocolate, bitterness, a tad harsh. Palate: Medium body. Soft carbonation. Slightly sticky mouthfeel. Overall: A tad harsh. Nice malt features.

Thanks to Jean-Michael for this one and many others that night! Pours a dark brown with a small offwhite head that leaves nice lacing. Nose is of roasted nuts, chocolate and light coffee. Taste is of chocolate, roasted grain husks and is moderately bitter. It has a "charred" character that Im not entirely fond of but still, this is a dark hoppy beer so I believe you can consider it to be normal. Body was medium, carbonation medium-high. Good beer, not something I usually seek but it was quite enjoyable overall.

bottle shared by John_Beer, thanks dude! pours unclear dark Brown, red tint, with a very nice light beige head, good retention and lacing. powdery chocolate, spicy roasted malts, dark coffee beans, coffee berries, dark red fruitiness, spicy citrus, cs indeed. moderately low carbonation, light body, very dru roasty-never overdone bitter coffee-citrusy finish. very solid!

Bottle (500 ml). Thanks to Jean-Michaël for sharing! Dark amber with a medium beige head and some lacing. Aroma is quite fruity with roasted malt, light resinous notes and hints of chocolate. Taste is also fruity with roasted malt, chocolate, resinous notes and light citrusy presence. Medium body. Medium carbonation. Silky mouthfeel. Fruity finish. Good balance. Easy drinking. Interesting Schwarzbier.

Nearly black color, tan head, good lace/retention. Aroma is hop dominated with notes of grapefruit and citrus. They completely overpower the chocolate malts and caramel sweetness. Medium bodied, moderate to high bitterness. Interesting take but not really true to the style. As a black IPA this would have scored higher.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Black - offwhite head. Nce hoppy, ok bitterness, burned malts, light sopay notes, resin, citrus, licorice, light sweet finish. OK.

Very good, especiallly as it opens up. Great looking with nice, thick tan head and lots of lacing topping a very dark beer. Malty and earthy, roasty, nice mouth feel, no off flavors, resiny. Pretty much excellent other than for me, just a bit too much hopping, which threw off the balance.

Bottle - thin black pour with mocha head. Nose is very earthy. Almost like dirt, mushrooms, and pepper. Taste follows the nose with some light hop bitterness and smoke. Not working for me but respect the effort. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to WillRunForBeer. Pours black with a huge foamy head that fades slowly and leaves chunky lacing. Aroma is nice mix of roast and hops. Ash, burnt wood, pine, light citrus, and light chocolate. Taste starts with a big pine hop punch which turns into bitter roasted coffee and burnt wood. The slightest hint of citrus too. Stinging, bitter, spicy hops in the finish. Medium to full body. Big foamy carbonation works well here. Delicious.

Bottle from Colonial Spirits.
Pours a clear dark brown with ruby highlights at the edges and a creamy fluffy tan head that persists forever. Aromas of floral spicy resinous hops with bits of bitter chocolate flakes and a hint of coffee. The flavor is rich chocolate and hints of coffee with a solid shot of earthy resinous hop flavor. Moderate hop bitterness lasting long into the finish of each sip. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation. Very nice black ipa, but it really does straddle the line of being a porter.
Great shwartz, fresh bottle from Premier Gourmet. Black, above average mouthfeel. Nice hopping. Lovely, seems bigger beer than it is, thats cool.

(Embouteillée le 11 mars 2014) La robe brune acajou montre sa coiffe tenace. Des morceaux de mousse restent collés durant toute la dégustation. Au nez, des conifères de toute sorte exhibent des parfums puissants qui contrôlent les vapeurs des grains chocolatés. Dans la deuxième moitié de la dégustation, des arômes sensuels de vanille. Au goût, les houblons sont en fleurs et en conifères. Je ne trouve aucune résine désagréable dans mon verre. Des céréales rôties, des touches terreuses et des pointes vanillées sélèvent au-dessus de la mêlée verte. Au palais, jai limpression dun corps de moyenne densité avec une texture crémeuse et un pétillement mou. En arrière-goût, la verdure des houblons et la force des malts rôtis sunissent pour établir une amertume modérément puissante et modérément longue. Très bonne bière. Savoureuse et tellement facile à boire. Une Black IPL? Une belle trouvaille faite à Richford, Vermont.
Dark with light cafe head. Very bitter upfront and slightly sweet which fades away nicely. Despite the huge bitter taste it is very easy to drink.

Taster at the brewery (and a bottle to myself later that evening). Dark brown pour with very little head. Malty and hoppy nose. Nice pine forward hop taste, slightly bitter finish. Good, but I like cascadian styles to hit a bit harder on the hop front.
Bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with tan head. Nose/taste of grassy hops, light smoke, pine, resin, citrus peel, coffee and slightly burnt toast. Medium body.

Bottle. Pours clear deep mahogany with a medium creamy tan head that dissipates slowly leaving hella nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is very hoppy, pine, grapefruit, roasted malts, chocolate. Flavor is light plus sweet and light bitter, bursting with hoppiness on top of a solid rich malty backbone; roasty, nutty with pine and citrus notes. Drinks like a black IPA, which is of course the point. Medium body, a bit creamy. Really nice.

Bottle at home I should have grabbed the rest of the Jacks Abby since so reasonably priced but oh well enjoy what I got. Pour wonderful dark brown with huge fluffy head. Nose is hoppy and roasted. Tastes of burnt toast, roasted malt, charcoal, light smoke, pine, grapefruit, and resin. Bitter finish.

Sampled this at Tap and Mallet total tap takeover. After all those Baltic Porters, this really stood out. Nice hop aroma and equally big hop flavor stood out in this dark brew. Hoppiest Schwarzbier that I ever had. Very good.

Decent but weird. Borrowing from Black IPA. On tap at total tap takeover at Tap and Mallet. Not one of my faves of the night, but decent. Very dark, orange highlights. Hoppy nose of cascade hops. Nutty with alternating hoppy and malty notes. Not your fathers scharzbier.

Looks like soda in a glass, dark purpleish brown with a small tan head around the rim of the glass. The nose is all classic American hops. Citrus, pine, and quite a bit of weed in there too. My neighbors actually started smoking as I was halfway through the glass, for a second I was really confused why the aroma of the beer go so powerful. Some minor woodsy roasted aromas and alcohol as well. The flavor allows the malts to take some prominence, surprisingly sweet and refreshing on top of the pine and citrus hops. Absolutely perfect mouthfeel, smooth and thick body that foams up a little as you swish it around. Good interpretation of the Black IPA from Jacks Abby, its certainly closer to that than a traditional Schwarzbier.

Bottle... Pours black with a small, creamy, mushroom-colored head. Terrific retention. Chocolate really stands out in the bouquet. Medium-bodied and lightly creamy with airy carbonation. The flavor is burnt, chocolaty, roasty and bitter. Charcoal and unsweetened black chocolate in the aftertaste. Muchos gracias to biggsbowler for sharing his bottle!

500ml bottle pours dark rich brown with light edges and 2 fingers of head. Nose is light roast chocolate, piney evergreen, fresh cut grass. Taste is balanced body with nice roasty soft chocolate malt, fresh grassy pine, subtle orange notes. Finish is medium bitterness, touches of roasty smoke, pine. Great!

16.9 ounce bottle poured into a tulip. Pours dark brownish black with 3 and a half fingers of fluffy off-white head. Nice webby lacing as the head recedes slowly. Aromas of pine, floral hops, chocolate, roast, light coffee. Tasting notes of big pine, resin, dark chocolate, caramel, roast, floral and piney hops. A bit of toffee and rye as well. Medium body with a dry finish. Medium carbonation, slightly creamy mouthfeel. Fantastic beer!

Poured from bottle into snifter: Pours black with a thin tan head. Aroma of pine, citrus, malt, and smoke. Taste is really nice, a lightly smoked slightly sweet lager, lots of roasted malt, and a resiny hop kick. Medium body, dry finish. Excellent beer.

500 ml bottle. Pours a dark brownish black with a large tight tan head. It quickly fades, leaves a lot of lacing. Aroma is pine and citrus, some tropical fruit and melon notes. Mild chocolate, roast, and ash notes. Flavor is crisp, hoppy, heavily bitter. Mostly pine and resin notes, light spruce. Upfront roasted and chocolate malt notes. Full bodied, creamy texture, finish is somewhat abrupt, mostly fruity.
Nice black pour tan head. Roasted malt aroma and some choppy characteristics. Medium smooth body with light carbonation. Clean. Roasted malt some sticky hop flavor hint of char. Good stuff.
draft at Blue Monk, great beer, medium to fuller bodied, big roastiness with a load of piney hops. Would favorably match up with any Black IPA

The beer pours a deep, chocolaty brown with a massive head of creamy, sand colored bubbles. The head sits two fingers widths above the glass with a nice lasting retention and a puzzle grid of thin lacing. On the nose, the beer smells delicately of roasted coffee beans and damp pine forests. Smooth dark chocolate works its way into the nose alongside musty earth and subtle dankness. The balance on the nose between hops and malt is quite nice and intriguing. As I sniff for longer I start to sense oranges dipped in chocolate, which is quite inviting. On the tongue, the beer tastes bitter with roast and hoppy bitters. The finish brings a splash of sweet chocolate and bready malts, and a pop of citric acidity also lingers in the finish. In flavor, the beer begins as sweet citrus lemon, quickly falling into bitter pine resin and decadently toasted bread, blending roasted coffee and espresso bean flavors through rich dark chocolates. Subtle grass and herbal hops work their way into the finish alongside a beautiful burp of milk chocolate and toasted oatmeal bread. The aftertaste is of moderately bitter pine resin, which sticks to the roof of the mouth. In the mouth, the beer feels on the light side of medium in body with a middling carbonation and a crisp, snappy mouthfeel that provides nice drinkability and scrubs away some of the heavier roast and bitter flavors. After the beer leaves, the mouth is left with slight spittle in the cheeks, soft bitter burn down the middle of the tongue, and a sticky resinous feel on the roof of the mouth. Overall, this is a beautifully balanced hoppy lager. Terrific pine and roasted malts tango on the tongue in a way that I very much appreciate. The closest thing to compare this to would be an American Black Ale, but this beer is miles ahead of that style in terms of balance. This could please a hop head and a roasted malt lover at the same time. Another superb beer from Jacks Abby.
Pours a dark brown with a tan lacing. Earthy hop notes of dirt and leaves, some grass and faint citrus. The aroma also consists of coffee and chocolate.
Bottle. Pours Coca cola brown with a beige head. Aroma of pine, citrus, roasted malt. Taste follows nose. Very smooth and well balanced.

Rcvd in trade. Reviewed from notes.
The appearance has a black/almost brown body thats a bit lighter around the edges and bottom of the pilsener, three finger white foamy head lasts for about three minutes and slowly dies as it sips.
The smell has roasted malt, slightly pine/resinous, citrus perhaps (really faint), but gets more piney/resinous as it warms.
The taste is dry and bitter through the previously mentioned flavors.
The palate is about a light to medium, ABV is not felt leading to a decent session, comes through fairly smooth, dry bitter aftertaste and finish.
Overall, I would say this is good for its style and I would have another.

Aroma of roasted maple malt and burnt pine sap. Dark brown with a two finger residual head. APA level bitterness for this lager, and of course plenty of semi-sweet toastiness. Palate cutting body which I found heavy but not exactly full like a porter would be. The hoppier the beer, the higher the RB score, as reflected here by a 99 style score. Bottled March 2013.

In short: A scented-coniferous hop orgy over chocolaty malts. A Schwarzbier for the Black IPA lover. Awkward perfumy hop profile that didnt work for me.
How: Bottle 500ml, consumed super-fresh a few days after purchase, bottle from lushawn but dont worry I disinfected the bottle.
The look: Clear dark ruby body topped by a large dark-beige head with good retention.
In long: The hop-forward nose is very coniferous, highly scented, a bit floral, and it all came together as almost perfume-like to me. Body is medium, plenty of soft bubbles, pillowy mouthfeel. In mouth the malts contribute a bit of flavor (slice of chocolate cake) but this beer is mainly a scented-coniferous hops orgy. Again that perfumy character. In a blind tasting, with the aroma and taste I would not have guessed this is a lager, this beer is so monstrously hoppy and with a hop bill that is so assertive that hops is pretty much all you taste. Very tasty but this was just not a type of hop bill that works for me. Can a beer like this be too fresh?!? I much prefer Jack Abbys more restrained creations. Given how much I usually love Jack Abby I was as disappointed as that time I thought I bought a ticket to see the greatest movie ever but it was a triple bill showing Transformers - Blow - GI Joe.

Bottle: The aroma consists of chocolate, caramel, roast, and a touch of pine. It pours a dark brown with some orange highlights and a small khaki head that quickly fades to a thin film outlined by a soapy ring. The flavor starts with a quick dose of dark chocolate and faint caramel. The finish has moderate pine and light roast. Its light-medium bodied light-moderate carbonation.
Bottle. Thanks Jeff!! Pours black with off white head. Hop and slight toasted aroma. Taste is very grass bitter lots of roasted malts. Slightly sweet.

500 ml bottle shared by DrSilverworm. Pours a dark cola brown color with a medium sized beige head. The aroma had roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, a splash of vanilla, with piney and earthy hops. The flavor opened with a big roasted malt and coffee burst; some earth and dark chocolate entered mid palate; the pine resiny notes were around throughout. Decent bitterness. This is a solid schwarzbier.

500ml bottle in a lager glass. Pours dark brown with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of citrusy and floral hops, roasted malts, and some dough. Flavor the same with a nice blend of everything. Average texture. The dark malts work well with the hops in this lager style beer.

Bottle, from the Beer Shop LTD, split at Tonys house - 19/05/13.
Mahogony brown with a light tan head.
Nose is dark malt, light soap, background hops, dark fruit.
Taste comprises dark malts, sugars, light smoke, dark toffee fudge, hoppy backnotes.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dryish finish.
A very good Schwarzbier!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: This is awful. Even for an IPA its bad. The after taste lingers in the very worse way. Its dark but gross. Hoppy but not happy. Its growing hair on the back of our tongues like felt. Take away: dont buy beer from Framingham. F-

Bottle @ home via trade with Ernesto987. Huge thanks! I just had two of the worst beers of my life and Im going to try to not let that influence this rating. Pours a deep brown/black appearance with a spidery, dark brown head and nice retention. An amazing huge and potent, coffee, roasty malty aroma with some piney, burnt malty, a touch smoky, light citrusy aroma. Chocolate, uber roasty, burnt/smoky malty, spicy, very potent, piney hoppy flavor that finishes quite dry. Over the top, American-style version of a German classic, but quite tasty. Sure, I really like this but fucken a bro, it aint the best Schwarzbier in the world, bros.

16.9oz bottle, thanks to Mike L. Shared with alexsdad06 and AndyReynolds. ABV labeled as 7%. Labeled "Cascadian Schwarzbier". Bottled March 2013. Dark brown color, nearly black, slightly clear around the edges. Good thin off-white slightly tan head. Nice lace. Nice big roasty malt flavor. Big piney, lightly earthy, herbal hop. Nice big spicy bitter taste. Medium to bigger body. Lighter, smooth carbonation. More dry texture. Nice long roasty piney herbal hop aftertaste. Some coffee in the aroma, light hint of chocolate. This stuff is awesome. Puts a lot of Black IPAs to shame. Love it. My kind of aggressive, assertive schwarzbier, never had one like this. Double version please?
Bottle thanks to DrSilverworm.  Odd for certain, complex.  Smokey and coffee in the aroma, but after it hits the taste buds it brings out the hops.

50cl bottle pours a nearly opaque black with maple edges and some rocky, lacing, beige head.  Aroma is excellent, dry toast, dried cocoa pods, blood oranges, pine needles, dried lemon peel, a little licorice.  Flavor is sweet but only just so, light caramel, some dark chocolate, light fruit, some light coffee grounds, a touch of cola.  Far more citrus in the flavor, oranges, blood oranges, grapefruit rind, pine, soap.  All of it is very clean and meshes very well.  Finishes super clean, a little soapy but not overly dry.  If this was an ale it would be a black IPA, no doubt.  Completely drinkable.  Delicious.  A great example of a German style lager with a distinctly American twist.
Black translucent pour with nice tan head.  Aroma is spruce and grapefruit with nice ashy roastyness.  Another dominating beer by jacks abbey.
Wow this is awesome, roasty an sweet and rich, tons of hops, this kicks asss

Thanks to LUSHawn! I pounded this one in under 10 seconds, bro!  Pours a inky thin black with an enormous head. Aromas of hoppy bliss and light roast. Pounded quickly, finished dry. Really fucken good.

March 2013 batch, 500 ml bottle into a HF wine glass.

A - Pours a jet black body that exposes some light around the edges. A few fingers worth of khaki foam sticks around for a while. Ungodly amounts of dirty, sticky lacing just coats the sides of the glass. 

S - Bright grapefruit, pine and charred malts and chocolate. It does that have uniquely Jacks Abby lager aroma to it. 

T - Not overly bitter or malty. Just pleasant piney hops meeting ever so lightly roasty chocolate malts. A touch of smoke on the end. Very clean and easy drinking. Mouth feel is medium bodied and silky.

O - A pleasantly hoppy schwarzbier, this was damn tasty and JA continues to amaze me with their innovative lagers.

Pours wall to wall black.  No color to be found.  Beige head.  Puffs up big with the initial pour.  Good lacing and retention.  Nailed the look.  The aroma is heavy on chocolate, molasses and doughy malt.  Some pine and citrus hoppiness in there, as well.  Theres more sweet roasted malt character than I expect from the style.  Its a pleasant aroma, but its more of a schwarzbier on steroids than a hoppy schwarzbier, at least in my opinion.  Im getting a fair bit of roast fruitiness.  Pretty rich.  Clean lager flavor.  The taste is fairly sweet and still quite rich.  Lots of fudge and treacle.  Big coffee and pine needle finish.  Again, over the top for the style, but still a very well made beer and quite tasty.  Im still not convinced that big hops and big roasted malt works well together, but this is a pleasant enough attempt, and Im sure fans of American Black Ales and whatnot will like this beer.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  A bit much for the style, but who cares.  This is a very good beer, and I would have called it an ale in a blind tasting. Knowing its a lager, I can bit out some of that clean yeastiness, but the hops and malt are too big for me to have guessed right.

Bottle - Pours with a foamy tan head above a deep brown body. Nose is citrusy hops mixed with fudge and pine. Taste has a piney, resinous hop bite throughout, mixed with a bready, fudgy malt base. Dry, bready finish. Fairly thin and well-carbonated. Overall its pretty smooth, and the dryness makes it fairly quenching. Good stuff.

Fudge brown pour with a black center, beige craggy head.  Aroma is dank pine surrounded by rich earthy chocolate, loam, crushed leaves, molasses, light wood smoke.  Creamy and supple in the mouth, with a long lingering finish.  Flavor is leafy, resinous hop, bittersweet chocolate, crushed autumn leaves, lightly roasted on the finish with a lingering, slightly vegetative, bitterness.  I cant get enough of this brewery these days.  Yum.

Bottle received from Allen, thanks again for another new Jacks Abby tick! Pours a dark brown black in color with two fingers worth of creme colored head. The head slowly recedes and leaves some frothy lacing as I drink. Nose is a balance of chocolate, some light smoke, and citrus on the finish. A lot of roasted malt and chocolate on the flavor and very little hop bite on the finish. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel, some very light bitterness, good carbonation, and a moderate finish. A nice, roasty schwarzbier. Easy drinking and a very pleasant flavor profile.
UPDATED: APR 4, 2014 (Critique chaotique du extreme beer fest 2013): Version cask aged w/cacao nibs, une autre bombe chocolatée au comptoir NERAX. Bien concue, buvabilité surprenante.

a nice fresh bottle.  wow.  a big nice hoppy black roasty lager.    real nice.  clean.  potent aroma of molasses kissed cocoa with a tight pine, citrus hop twang.  nice.   lasting bitter roast and pine.   pretty tasty.   like a nice blackipa, but lager.    one of my favorites from jacks abby.   when this brewery is on it is a real treat.

Single 475 mL bottle purchased from Learys for $3.80. To snifter it pours a ruby-tinted rusty brown (shown as a mysterious dark tone in glass) with which a big, frothy tan head was erected upon. Two fingers in length. Wow; aromas of pine needles, squash purée, lager yeast, figs, topsoil, maple leafs, acorns, bourbon vanilla ice cream, molasses, and blood orange. I honestly could smell this all day. Tastes of piny and earthy hops, common figs, black liquorice, burnt rubber,  ash, and plastic.Seaweed, algae, and walnuts too when let out to warm. Caramelized onions, yeast, growing heat, and nail polish by swallow. Good beer; I didnt completely enjoy the flavors in its end-palate, but this is nevertheless a delightful Schwarzbier. I recommend buying a bottle.

a little heavier on the roasted malt character than I prefer, but acceptable for the style.  good hop aroma, but I feel its lessened by the heavy dose of high-dried malts. flavors are beautifully blended earthy-pine-spice from hops, and roasted, slightly acrid malt character.  Good medium-dense mouthfeel, creamy and satisfying.
One of the better beers Ive tasted in a while.  Well-hopped and still with a long palate and nuanced taste.  Wow.

A - Pours a dark black with a hint of brown around the edges and a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of roasted earthy malts with some light smoke, cocoa, vanilla, and some pine and earthy hops.

T - Starts off with roasted dark and earthy malts with some light vanilla and smoke. Through the middle some cocoa comes through with some pine and earthy hops and a bit of bitterness. The finish is a mix of roasted cocoa and earthy malts with a bit of vanilla and smoke and a touch of citrus hop and bitterness.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry and lightly roasted and bitter finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really great smoothness and texture with a great balance of flavors. A really nice dark lager.
Malt and citrus hops in the aroma.  Flavor starts with malt and roast, and finishes with piney bitterness.  Different, but it works.

Big thanks to myspoonistoobig for getting me out a bottle of this one. Served in a Mikasa pilsner glass.

Pours near black with a thick tan head. Great retention and plenty of sticking lacing as it eventually falls to a thin cap.

The nose carries a bit of light Cascade and orange with some nice roasted malt in the background. The flavor follows suit, but the hops come more to the front, melding quite well with the roast. Roast with a touch of coffee plus orange peel and citrus. Theres a bit of light earth and pine in the background.

Mouthfeel is medium with good carbonation and a nice combo between the roast and bitterness through the finish.

Nice concept and well-executed. I think this could use a touch more in the nose, but other than that this is a really nice brew.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2012 500mL Bottle, purchased at Julios Liquors - Westborough, MA. I continue to be blown away by the work from these guys. Absolutely my new favorite brewery. This one cracks open with a rich and balanced hop and lightly toasted malt aroma. Fresh and efferevescent. The lacing is supreme. Flavors wane back and forth between a pungent pine and citrus hop punch and a gentle, but substantial, supporting and well built malt base. Fantastically clean fresh and drinkable.

Came out jet black with a huge 3 inch tan head. Light hoppy-coffee aromas. Flavor is complex: lots of chocolate and coffee malts. Great hop balance. Still, much lighter in body than a stout. Buy more complex too. light sweet and bittering finish. Very tasty and enjoyable!

.5 liter bottle dated February 2012. Thanks to Reagan1984 for this. 

Appearance- Dark brown that lightens around the edges. Big thick tan head. Great lacing.  4.5/5

Smell- Earthy hop aroma accompanied with some roasted malt smells.

Taste- Roasted malt flavors are first. Nice even earthy hop bitterness in the end. Well balanced.

Mouthfeel- Nice even mouthfeel that trends to the thin side 

Overall- This is a great beer. Very easy to drink and it is not trying to be something it is not. Very well crafted beer.

Half Liter Bottle. Pours a dark burgundy with a lasting off white head which left a decent lacing. Nice hoppy aroma, big roasted malt flavors with a bitter hop finish. Not sure if it is a home town bias in play here but I am loving everything from these guys.

Bottle from Julios. Deep brown with red highlights in my mug. Thick, full white head having excellent retention and layers of lace. Roasted malt and light Earthy hop nose. Flavor does have the typical roasted malt, chocolate and German malt of the style. However, this is by far the most hoppy Schwarzbier I have ever drank. Strong bitterness in the finish, comparable to a strong IPA or black IPA. Roasted notes and German malt helps balance this brew. Tasty.

Pours mahogany-tinged black into a Sam glass. Significant pancake head with excellent retention recedes leaving sheet lacing. Sweet, dark chocolate, toasted nut and resin aromas. Medium to full bodied with dark caramel, roasted dark chocolate turning to pine in the lasting finish.

Bottle brought directly from brewery.

Footnote...I continue to be impressed by Jacks Abby, as the brewery grows their beers continue to surprise me.

Aroma- A very balanced yet obvious nose consisting of fruity tones and roasted notes.  Light floral notes can also be found.

Appearance - nice dark color almost black but some mahogany highlights.  Large frothy off-white head that sticks with the beer throughout.

Taste - roasted witha v ery nice balance of hops.  A little citrusy and florally with a good amount of bitterness that balances the beer nicely.  Aftertaste is fairly bitter and long lasting.

Nice mouthfeel, easy drinker.  Crisp medium bodied lager that is balanced nicely.

Def. will drink again.
